channel.title: NPR Topics: Technology
channel.description: Latest technology news and breakthroughs in technology, science, and industry. Download the NPR Technology podcast and Technology RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Once an industry top dog, Intel hopes to regain dominance with chip made in the U.S.
item.description: Intel has announced the launch of a chip that's made in America. Analysts say the Core Ultra Series Three could help the California-based company regain its dominance in the chip industry.
item.content:encoded: Intel has announced the launch of a chip that's made in America. Analysts say the Core Ultra Series Three could help the California-based company regain its dominance in the chip industry.
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: A $400,000 profit on Maduro's capture raises insider trading questions on Polymarket
item.description: Online sleuths have tried to uncover who placed a winning bet on the Venezuelan leader's arrest to no avail. Still, prediction market watchers say the bet appears suspicious.
item.content:encoded:
Online sleuths have tried to uncover who placed a winning bet on the Venezuelan leader's arrest to no avail. Still, prediction market watchers say the bet appears suspicious.

(Image credit: Juan Barreto)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: The crafters powering the AI boom
item.description: America's AI boom requires a lot of power. NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Wall Street Journal reporter Jennifer Hiller about the workers who are building the electric grid one transformer at a time.
item.content:encoded: America's AI boom requires a lot of power. NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Wall Street Journal reporter Jennifer Hiller about the workers who are building the electric grid one transformer at a time.
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: AI-powered software is helping misinformation spread online after disasters
item.description: Misinformation after disasters is growing in part because AI-powered software makes it easier to create and spread lies on social media.
item.content:encoded: Misinformation after disasters is growing in part because AI-powered software makes it easier to create and spread lies on social media.
item.dc:creator: Justin Hicks

item.title: The year in AI and culture
item.description: From the advent of AI actress Tilly Norwood to major music labels making deals with AI companies, 2025 has been a watershed year for AI and culture.
item.content:encoded: From the advent of AI actress Tilly Norwood to major music labels making deals with AI companies, 2025 has been a watershed year for AI and culture.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman

item.title: Memory loss: As AI gobbles up chips, prices for devices may rise
item.description: Demand for memory chips currently exceeds supply and there's little chance of that changing anytime soon. More chips for AI means fewer available for other products such as computers and phones. That could drive up those prices too.
item.content:encoded:
Demand for memory chips currently exceeds supply and there's little chance of that changing anytime soon. More chips for AI means fewer available for other products such as computers and phones. That could drive up those prices too.

(Image credit: Charlie Litchfield)
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: Why do airline computer systems fail? What the industry can learn from meltdowns
item.description: Alaska Airlines is the latest airline to ground its planes because of an IT meltdown. We talked to industry leaders about why these systems fail, and what airlines can learn from past disruptions.
item.content:encoded:
Alaska Airlines is the latest airline to ground its planes because of an IT meltdown. We talked to industry leaders about why these systems fail, and what airlines can learn from past disruptions.

(Image credit: Stephen Brashear)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: When will quantum computing deliver on its promise?
item.description: Governments and tech companies continue to pour money into quantum technology in the hopes of building a supercomputer that can work at speeds we can't yet fathom to solve big problems.
item.content:encoded: Governments and tech companies continue to pour money into quantum technology in the hopes of building a supercomputer that can work at speeds we can't yet fathom to solve big problems.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Vince Zampella, video game pioneer behind megahit Call of Duty, dies at 55
item.description: One of Vince Zampella's crowning achievements was the creation of the Call of Duty franchise, which has sold more than half a billion games worldwide.
item.content:encoded:
One of Vince Zampella's crowning achievements was the creation of the Call of Duty franchise, which has sold more than half a billion games worldwide.

(Image credit: Paul Sakuma)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: How a power outage in Colorado caused U.S. official time to be 4.8 microseconds off
item.description: Officials said the error is likely too minute for the general public to clock it, but it could affect applications such as critical infrastructure, telecommunications and GPS signals.
item.content:encoded:
Officials said the error is likely too minute for the general public to clock it, but it could affect applications such as critical infrastructure, telecommunications and GPS signals.

(Image credit: J. Sherman, R. Jacobson)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez
